## Cherish This World Series. It’s the Last One Entirely in Human Hands. - <small>`nytimes`</small>

- [source](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/24/opinion/world-series-robo-umpires.html)
- _Published: 2025-10-24 05:02:44-04:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `baseball, technology, automation, human error, sports culture, imperfection, sports technology, 2025 world series, A.B.S. system, Armando Galarraga, Mookie Betts, Orion Kerkering, Anette Hosoi, Joe Torre, Morgan Sword`</small>

### Summary

The 2025 World Series will be the last championship in Major League Baseball to be fully decided by human umpires. Starting in 2026, the Automated Ball-Strike (A.B.S.) system will be implemented, using computer-generated strike zones based on player height to replace human judgment. While technology offers precision, critics argue that the game’s emotional depth, unpredictability, and human imperfections — such as the near-perfect game by Armando Galarraga and errors like Orion Kerkering’s — are what make baseball memorable and authentic. Experts like Anette Hosoi and former umpire Jim Joyce emphasize that the human element, including mistakes and emotional responses, is integral to the game’s charm. As technology advances, the article warns that removing human judgment may ultimately make baseball less engaging and less human.

### Key Takeaways
  - The 2025 World Series will be the last to be fully adjudicated by human umpires, as the A.B.S. system begins integration in 2026.
  - The A.B.S. system uses a computer-defined strike zone based on a player’s height, setting the top at 53.5% and the bottom at 27% of the player’s height, eliminating human variability.
  - Critics argue that technology undermines the unpredictability, humanity, and emotional depth that define baseball’s charm and appeal.
  - Players and former umpires such as Joe Torre and Jim Joyce emphasize that baseball thrives on imperfection, mistakes, and human error — elements that create memorable, authentic moments.
  - The incident involving Armando Galarraga’s nearly perfect game in 2010, where a human error cost him the official title, led to a profound brotherhood and a book titled 'Nobody’s Perfect', symbolizing the value of human fallibility.
  - Experts like Anette Hosoi of M.I.T. Sports Lab argue that the game is more engaging when imperfect, and that human judgment adds narrative and emotional depth.

### Named Entities
- **2025 World Series**
    - The championship series of Major League Baseball that will be the last fully human-adjudicated game in history.
    - The 2025 World Series is the final championship series to be entirely decided by human umpires, marking a pivotal transition to automation.
- **Automated Ball-Strike (A.B.S.)**
    - A technology system that uses computer algorithms to determine balls and strikes based on player height and pitch data.
    - The A.B.S. system is the central technological innovation being introduced in 2026 to automate strike zone decisions, challenging traditional human umpiring.
- **Armando Galarraga**
    - A former Detroit Tigers pitcher who nearly achieved a perfect game in 2010, only to have it undone by a human umpire error.
    - Galarraga’s near-perfect game illustrates the human element in baseball and how errors can become symbolic of the game’s emotional and human depth.
- **Jim Joyce**
    - Former first-base umpire who botched the final call in Galarraga’s nearly perfect game in 2010.
    - Joyce’s error led to a lasting human connection with Galarraga and symbolizes the value of imperfection in baseball.
- **Giancarlo Stanton**
    - A Major League Baseball player whose height is used as a reference point in the A.B.S. system.
    - Stanton’s height is referenced in the article to illustrate how the A.B.S. system calculates strike zones based on individual player height.
- **Mookie Betts**
    - Dodgers shortstop known for a brilliant defensive play that was followed by a miscue from a relief pitcher.
    - Betts’ play and the subsequent error by Orion Kerkering highlight the role of human mistakes in making baseball memorable and unpredictable.
- **Orion Kerkering**
    - Philadelphia Phillies relief pitcher who made a critical error in the final play of a game, throwing the ball high and wide.
    - Kerkering’s error exemplifies the emotional impact of human lapses in baseball, reinforcing the idea that mistakes are part of the game’s charm.
- **Joe Torre**
    - Former manager of the New York Yankees, known for his belief in baseball’s unpredictability.
    - Torre emphasizes that unpredictability and the unexpected are central to baseball’s appeal and emotional resonance.
- **Anette Hosoi**
    - Co-founder of the M.I.T. Sports Lab and professor of engineering and mathematics.
    - Hosoi provides expert insight on how human imperfection enhances the game’s appeal, arguing that automation removes the narrative and emotional depth of baseball.
- **Morgan Sword**
    - Executive vice president of baseball operations at M.L.B.
    - Sword represents the league leadership and comments on player resistance to full automation, reflecting broader sentiment among athletes.
- **Jane Leavy**
    - Author of books on baseball figures including Babe Ruth, Sandy Koufax, and Mickey Mantle.
    - Leavy is cited as a voice of critical reflection on baseball’s current issues, including the role of human error and tradition.

### Important Dates
  - **2026-04-01**
    - The start of Opening Day 2026 marks the first time in MLB history when the Automated Ball-Strike (A.B.S.) system will be used in the World Series, signaling a major shift toward fully automated strike zone decisions.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2019_ to _2025_**
    - Since 2019, the A.B.S. system has undergone testing and development, leading to its eventual implementation in the majors by 2026, demonstrating a long-term technological trajectory in baseball.
